text: The way I learned how to pitch in business school, and I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor. So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatments. And the structure that I read about in these movies was different. Every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world, and I call this shift the shift from the old game to a new game.
speaker: Andy Raskin
context: Andy introduces his background and explains how he discovered a different approach to pitching. He contrasts the traditional business school method (which he calls the 'arrogant doctor' approach) with the storytelling structure he learned from screenwriting books. The 'arrogant doctor' method focuses on presenting problems and solutions, while his preferred approach starts by establishing a fundamental shift happening in the world - from an old way of doing things to a new way.
vocabulary_highlights: shift from the old game to a new game
text_ko: 제가 비즈니스 스쿨에서 피치를 배우면서 느낀 점은, 대부분의 사람들이 배우는 방식이 마치 자만하는 의사 같다는 거예요. 당신에게 문제가 있고, 고통이 있다면, 저는 해결책과 치료법을 가지고 있고, 그게 다른 치료법보다 왜 더 좋은지 설명할 거예요. 그런데 제가 읽었던 영화들에서의 구조는 달랐어요. 모든 영화는 세상에 어떤 변화가 일어나는 것으로 시작하는데, 저는 이 변화를 '구 게임에서 새로운 게임으로의 전환'이라고 부릅니다.
text_zh: 我在商学院学的那套pitch方式，我觉得大多数人学的都是我说的"傲慢医生"那一套。就是你有问题，有痛点，我有解决方案，有治疗方法，然后我要告诉你为什么我的比其他所有方案都好。但我从这些电影里看到的结构不一样。每部电影都是从世界的某种变化开始的，我把这种变化叫做从旧游戏规则到新游戏规则的转变。
text_es: La forma en que aprendí a hacer presentaciones en la escuela de negocios, y creo que la mayoría de la gente también, es lo que yo llamo el doctor arrogante. O sea, tú tienes un problema, un dolor, yo tengo una solución, un tratamiento, y te voy a decir por qué es mejor que todos los otros tratamientos. Pero la estructura que leí en estas películas era diferente. Cada película empieza con algún tipo de cambio en el mundo, y a este cambio yo lo llamo el cambio del juego viejo al juego nuevo.
key_sentence: The structure shifts from the arrogant doctor to defining a new game.

text: This structure really is about defining a movement, and that's very different from, 'Hey, I'm going to solve your problem.' What I think is really interesting as a kind of qualifier is that this story has a certain structure. And the traditional structure, the way I learned how to pitch in business school, I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor.
speaker: Andy Raskin
context: Lenny asks Andy to define what a strategic narrative is. Andy explains that it's one story that CEOs use to drive success across marketing, sales, product, fundraising, and recruiting. He emphasizes that this approach is about defining a movement rather than simply solving problems. Andy contrasts his recommended structure with the traditional 'arrogant doctor' approach where you present a problem and then explain why your solution is better than competitors.
text_ko: 이 구조는 사실 어떤 운동(movement)을 정의하는 것에 관한 거예요. 그리고 그건 '내가 네 문제를 해결해 줄게'라는 식의 접근과는 완전히 달라요. 흥미로운 건 이 이야기에 일정한 구조가 있다는 점이에요. 제가 비즈니스 스쿨에서 피칭(pitch)을 배우면서 익힌 전통적인 방식, 즉 대부분 사람들이 해오던 방식은 제가 '거만한 의사(arrogant doctor)'라고 부르는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 这个框架其实就是在定义一个运动，这和"嘿，我来帮你解决问题"是完全不同的概念。我觉得特别有意思的一点是，这个故事有它特定的结构。而传统的那套结构，也就是我在商学院学的那种推销方式，我想大多数人学的都是这样，我把它叫做"傲慢医生"模式。
text_es: Esta estructura realmente se trata de definir un movimiento, y eso es muy diferente a decir "Oye, te voy a resolver tu problema." Lo que me parece realmente interesante como una especie de criterio es que esta historia tiene una estructura específica. Y la estructura tradicional, la forma en que aprendí a hacer presentaciones en la escuela de negocios, creo que la forma en que la mayoría de la gente lo hizo, es lo que yo llamo el doctor arrogante.
key_sentence: Defining a movement differs from simply solving a problem.

text: What's really, I think key is naming it, naming that old game. The examples you saw, software, cloud, transactions, subscription opinions, reality. This very, very concise naming is really key. And it's hard because in making it compact you're losing completeness. So you can imagine you're in a meeting, someone says like, 'Hey, how about we do transactions to subscriptions?' And someone says, 'Well I don't know, there's a lot of things I don't really subscribe to. Subscription economy, really?' So we're always kind of overstating it in a way, but it's not a problem.
speaker: Andy Raskin
context: Lenny asks Andy to explain the framework for strategic narratives in more detail. Andy explains that one crucial element is naming both the old game and new game very concisely - like 'software to cloud' or 'transactions to subscriptions.' He acknowledges that this compact naming requires some oversimplification and that people might challenge whether the shift is really as universal as claimed, but argues this isn't actually a problem in practice.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 핵심은 그걸 이름 붙이는 거예요 — 그 오래된 방식을 이름으로 규정하는 것. 방금 보신 예들, 소프트웨어(software), 클라우드(cloud), 트랜잭션(transactions), 구독(subscription) 같은 아주 간결한 네이밍이 정말 중요해요. 근데 간결하게 하다 보면 완전성을 잃게 되니까 어려워요. 회의에서 누군가 ‘트랜잭션에서 구독으로 해볼까요?(transactions to subscriptions)’라고 하면, 다른 사람이 ‘글쎄요, 제가 꼭 구독하고 싶은 게 다 있는 건 아니에요. 구독 경제(subscription economy)라니, 정말?’이라고 말할 수 있잖아요. 그래서 우리는 어쩔 수 없이 어느 정도 과장해서 표현하긴 하는데, 그게 문제되진 않아요.
text_zh: 我觉得最关键的其实就是给它起个名字，把那套老玩法给定义出来。你们刚才看到的那些例子，软件啊、云啊、交易啊、订阅模式啊什么的。这种特别简洁的命名真的很关键。但难就难在，你要做得简洁，就肯定会丢掉一些完整性。你可以想象一下，开会的时候有人说："嘿，咱们要不试试从交易模式转到订阅模式？"然后就有人说："我不太确定啊，有很多东西我其实不太认同订阅这个说法。订阅经济(subscription economy)，真的吗？"所以我们其实总是在某种程度上夸大其词，但这不是问题。
text_es: Lo que creo que es clave de verdad es ponerle nombre, nombrar ese juego anterior. Los ejemplos que vieron - software, nube (cloud), transacciones, suscripciones, opiniones, realidad. Esa forma tan, tan concisa de nombrarlo es realmente clave. Y es difícil porque al hacerlo compacto pierdes completitud. Entonces te puedes imaginar que estás en una junta, alguien dice "Oye, ¿qué tal si pasamos de transacciones a suscripciones?" Y alguien más dice "Pues no sé, hay muchas cosas a las que realmente no me suscribiría. ¿Economía de suscripciones, en serio?" Entonces siempre estamos como exagerando un poco, pero no es problema.
key_sentence: Concise naming is key, but risks overstating it in a way.

text: And whenever I work with teams and I talk about this, so they're like, 'Okay, I guess we got to then for kill the prospect's aunt and uncle,' and basically yes, I mean figuratively. We got to show them that the future is not going to just be sort of okay. They see it as split between a very negative outcome and a potentially very positive outcome.
speaker: Andy Raskin
context: Andy uses a Star Wars analogy to explain how to create urgency in strategic narratives. He references how Luke Skywalker initially refuses the call to adventure until his aunt and uncle are killed, making the stakes life-and-death. Andy explains that in business pitches, you need to show prospects that their future won't be 'sort of okay' - there will be clear winners and losers based on whether they adapt to the new paradigm or stick with the old way.
vocabulary_highlights: kill the prospect's aunt and uncle
text_ko: 제가 팀들과 이 얘기를 하면 사람들이 농담 반으로 "그럼 잠재 고객(prospect)의 이모·삼촌을 죽여야 한다는 거예요?"라고 해요. 말하자면 비유적인 표현이에요. 우리가 보여줘야 할 건 미래가 그냥 그럭저럭 괜찮을 거라는 식이 아니라는 거예요. 그들은 미래를 아주 부정적인 결과와 잠재적으로 매우 긍정적인 결과로 나눠서 보고 있어요.
text_zh: 每次我跟团队讲这个的时候，他们就会说，'好吧，那我们得把潜在客户的七大姑八大姨都给'搞定'了'，基本上就是这个意思，当然是比喻啦。我们得让他们明白，未来不会就这么平平淡淡的。要让他们看到两个极端：要么结果很糟糕，要么有可能非常好。
text_es: Y siempre que trabajo con equipos y hablo de esto, me dicen: "Bueno, entonces supongo que tenemos que matar a los tíos del prospecto," y básicamente sí, pero en sentido figurado. Tenemos que demostrarles que el futuro no va a ser simplemente más o menos bien. Tienen que verlo dividido entre un resultado muy negativo y otro potencialmente muy positivo.
key_sentence: We must figuratively kill the prospect's aunt and uncle to show future outcomes.

text: Another thing I just hear always, I just interviewed a CEO this morning for my podcast and this is the first thing he actually said was, 'It becomes the strategic north star for the product.' So what he was telling me, and this was actually a little unusual, I asked him, 'Why did you come to me at first?' And of course I'd asked him that before, but he said something this time that was a little different from what I'd heard before. He said, 'We are constantly getting feature requests through sales, through customer success. And we had sort of no way, bar to decide well what do we take on, what don't we take on? And this clearly has become our bar.'
speaker: Andy Raskin
context: Lenny asks about the impact Andy has seen from companies shifting to his strategic narrative approach. Andy explains that beyond helping with sales and marketing, the strategic narrative becomes a decision-making framework for product development. A CEO Andy recently interviewed explained that they were constantly receiving feature requests from sales and customer success teams but had no clear criteria for prioritization until they developed their strategic narrative, which now serves as their filter for what features to build.
text_ko: 또 늘 듣는 얘기가 하나 있어요. 오늘 아침 팟캐스트에서 CEO를 인터뷰했는데, 그가 제일 먼저 한 말이 "이게 제품의 전략적 북극성(strategic north star)이 된다"였어요. 그가 제게 하려던 얘기는 이러했는데, 좀 특이한 점도 있었어요. 제가 "처음에 왜 저한테 오셨나요?"라고 물었더니, 전에 물어본 적도 있지만 이번엔 전과는 조금 다른 답을 주더라고요. 그는 "우리는 영업(sales)과 고객 성공(customer success)을 통해 계속 기능 요청(feature requests)을 받고 있어요. 그런데 무엇을 수용하고 무엇을 안 할지 판단할 기준(bar)이 사실상 없었어요. 그런데 이게 분명 우리의 기준이 됐어요."라고 말했어요.
text_zh: 还有一件事我经常听到，今天早上我在播客里采访了一个CEO，他第一句话就是："这成了我们产品的战略北极星(strategic north star)。" 他跟我说的是，其实挺特别的，我问他："你当初为什么来找我？" 当然我之前也问过他这个问题，但这次他说的跟以前有点不一样。他说："我们总是从销售那边、从客服成功(customer success)那边收到各种功能需求，我们根本没办法决定哪些该做，哪些不该做。现在这个就成了我们的标准。"
text_es: Otra cosa que escucho siempre, justo esta mañana entrevisté a un CEO para mi podcast y esto fue lo primero que me dijo: "Se convierte en la estrella polar estratégica del producto (strategic north star)". Entonces lo que me estaba diciendo, y esto sí fue un poco raro, le pregunté: "¿Por qué viniste conmigo en primer lugar?" Y claro, ya le había preguntado eso antes, pero esta vez me dijo algo un poquito diferente a lo que había escuchado antes. Me dijo: "Constantemente nos llegan solicitudes de funcionalidades a través de ventas, a través de customer success. Y no teníamos como una forma, un criterio para decidir qué tomamos y qué no tomamos. Y esto claramente se ha convertido en nuestro criterio."
key_sentence: The strategic north star becomes the bar to decide on feature requests.

text: But I guess I feel like still by calling it category and category name, we're just focusing on those three words so much. And what happens often is CEOs will, they'll kind of come up with this little category, like what happened with Nick at the 360Learning with collaborative learning. We have this name, but we don't know how to tell the story around it. So my feeling is like, well, let's focus on the story.
speaker: Andy Raskin
context: Lenny asks Andy about his perspective on category creation, noting that Andy doesn't seem to be a big fan of this popular approach. Andy explains that while he's not entirely against category creation, he believes people get too focused on finding the perfect category name (usually three words) rather than developing the underlying story. He argues that CEOs often create category names but then struggle to build a compelling narrative around them, which is why he prefers to focus on story and movement creation first.
vocabulary_highlights: come up with this little category
text_ko: 근데 저는 여전히 '카테고리(category)'나 '카테고리 이름'이라는 말에만 너무 집착하는 것 같아요. 그리고 자주 있는 일은 CEO들이 작은 카테고리를 만들어놓고—360Learning의 Nick 사례처럼 '협업 학습(collaborative learning)'이라는 이름은 있는데—그걸 둘러싼 이야기를 어떻게 풀어야 할지 모르는 거예요. 그래서 제 생각에는 이야기에 집중하자는 거예요.
text_zh: 但我觉得吧，我们老是纠结在"品类"和"品类名称"这几个词上，太钻牛角尖了。经常发生的情况就是，CEO们会想出一个小品类概念，就像Nick在360Learning搞的那个协作学习(collaborative learning)一样。名字是有了，但不知道怎么讲好这个故事。所以我的想法是，咱们还是把重点放在讲故事上吧。
text_es: Pero creo que al seguir llamándolo categoría y nombre de categoría, nos estamos enfocando demasiado en esas tres palabras. Y lo que pasa seguido es que los CEOs van a inventarse esta pequeña categoría, como lo que pasó con Nick en 360Learning con el aprendizaje colaborativo. Tenemos este nombre, pero no sabemos cómo contar la historia alrededor de él. Entonces mi sensación es que, bueno, enfoquémonos en la historia.
key_sentence: CEOs often come up with this little category but struggle to tell the story.

text: Well, I can tell you what I hear from CEOs when they contact me. I always ask, what's happening? Because that idea I had, no CEO's going to budget a line item for this. I'm basically asking, why was I wrong? So a few things they tell me, one is that the company is maturing from a point a stage where they've been successful, but that success is ... one CEO put it this way, was brute force of the founders.
speaker: Andy Raskin
context: Lenny asks what signs indicate that a company should work on their strategic narrative. Andy explains that he originally thought no CEO would budget for narrative work, so he always asks CEOs why they're reaching out. One common scenario is when companies are maturing beyond the stage where success depended on the founders being directly involved in every decision - what one CEO called 'brute force of the founders' - and they need a way to scale their vision and decision-making across the growing organization.
vocabulary_highlights: budget a line item for this
text_ko: 글쎄요, CEO들이 연락할 때 제가 듣는 얘기를 말씀드릴게요. 저는 항상 "무슨 일이죠?"라고 물어요. 제 생각엔 그 아이디어에 대해 어떤 CEO도 이걸 위해 예산 항목(line item)을 잡지 않을 거라고 생각하니까요. 사실 제가 묻는 건, "제가 왜 틀렸지?"예요. 그들이 제게 하는 얘기 중 몇 가지가 있는데, 하나는 회사가 성공을 거둔 단계에서 한 단계 더 성숙해지고 있다는 거예요. 그런데 그 성공은… 한 CEO가 그러더군요, 창업자들이 힘으로 밀어붙여 얻은 성공(brute force)이라고요.
text_zh: 我可以跟你说说那些CEO联系我的时候都跟我反映什么。我总是会问，到底出了什么事？因为我那个想法，没有哪个CEO会专门为这个事儿单独做预算的。我基本上就是在问，我哪里想错了？他们跟我说的情况主要有这么几个，其中一个就是公司正在从一个阶段走向成熟，之前他们是成功的，但是这种成功...有个CEO是这么说的，完全就是靠创始人的蛮干。
text_es: Bueno, te puedo contar lo que escucho de los CEOs cuando me contactan. Siempre les pregunto, ¿qué está pasando? Porque con esa idea que tenía, ningún CEO va a meter una partida presupuestaria para esto. Básicamente estoy preguntando, ¿en qué me equivoqué? Entonces me dicen varias cosas, una es que la empresa está madurando desde un punto, una etapa donde han tenido éxito, pero ese éxito es... un CEO lo puso así, fue por la fuerza bruta de los fundadores.
key_sentence: No CEO will budget a line item for this; success relies on the brute force of founders.
